attributes.comment:
Dear Mr. Chertoff,
I strongly oppose your intention to raise the CIS fees as the fee hike is too
severe and will become cost-prohibiting for many eligible persons to apply for
benefits. This fee hike will force immigrants who have various family members
that simultaneously qualify for benefits not to be able to file together because
these fees are so exorbitant. If CIS is fee based, how does it plan on
surviving if filings significantly drop off because immigrants can't afford the
fees?
I heard the argument that $295 for citizenship is very low and does not reflect
the value of this honor. To those who said that, I would ask them to take into
account the full price tag for the entire process. To become a citizen one must
first have a visa, then a green card, then after security and medical checks one
can apply for citizenship. This process is currently costing way over $10,000 if
you take into account all paperwork fees and an affordable attorney who can
maneuver through the complex system. If doubling and tripling fees will ensure a
smooth process where applicants do not have to hire an expert, have to pay for
all other extras and the service improves, then I would consider it a step
forward. However, USCIS has raised fees in the past only to keep backlogs
growing and service diminishing. No valid argument has been raised for this
outrageous fee hike.
A small fee hike may understandable but doubling or tripling the fees is
unreasonable and severe and I urge you to reconsider. Thank you.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Andrea Leon-Grossmann
